user_message:
<misra_rule>
MISRA C 2023 Rule 17.2 is: Functions shall not call themselves, either directly or indirectly.

</misra_rule>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- is_rule_violated: whether the rule is violated or not (true/false),
- scenario: a specific violation scenario.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of check_apply_param__threads:
```c
static void
check_apply_param__threads (void)
{
  if (0 == tool_params.threads)
    return;

  num_threads = tool_params.threads;

  if (get_process_cpu_core_count () < num_threads)
  {
    fprintf (stderr, "WARNING: The requested number of threads (%u) is "
             "higher than the number of detected available CPU cores (%u).\n",
             num_threads, get_process_cpu_core_count ());
    fprintf (stderr, "This decreases the performance. "
             "Consider using fewer threads.\n");
  }
  if (get_cpu_core_count () == num_threads)
  {
    printf ("The requested number of threads is equal to the number of "
            "detected CPU cores.\n");
    print_all_cores_used ();
  }
}
```
</target_code>
<target_code>
Here is the code fragment that you need to analyze:
```c
if (get_process_cpu_core_count () < num_threads)
```
Focus on the above code fragment and judge whether it violates the rule 17.2 or not.
</target_code>
scenario: The fragment calls get_process_cpu_core_count(), which by itself does not constitute recursion. There is no evidence in the provided code that get_process_cpu_core_count either directly calls check_apply_param__threads or indirectly does so via another chain of calls. Therefore Rule 17.2 is not violated. (If get_process_cpu_core_count were implemented to call check_apply_param__threads — directly or through other functions — that would create an indirect recursion and would violate Rule 17.2.)
